section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary (snug, grin).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What different family members do you hear about in the story?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children describe the activity in the picture.
Challenge children to identify the different family members they see in the pictures.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How many families can you find in that book? How many people are in the family?
Who in your family can you pretend to be? How will you act?
How can you sort the people in your family into different groups?
Who in your family can you draw?
What materials can you use to make little figures of the people in your family?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word family? Can you say the letter?
Can you use blocks to make a house for the family you made?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder use your imagination and introduce vocabulary (imagination, watch).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to First Laugh—Welcome, Baby!
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children use their imaginations to discuss what the families are doing in the picture.
Guide children to imagine what it might be like to do the same activities.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a family that is celebrating a special day?
Can you try to make someone laugh?
Can you count how many brothers and sisters the children in your group have?
What does your family like to do for fun? Can you draw a picture that shows this?
Can you make tiny versions of some of your family’s favorite foods?
Find the letters that spell the name of one person in your family.
Use your imagination to build a fun house for your family.

Text copyright © 2018 by Nancy Bo Flood and Rose Ann Tahe. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Jonathan Nelson. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc. section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Ask Questions and introduce vocabulary (spinning, giggles).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What different family members do you hear about in the story?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Work with children to make individual books about what makes their families special.
Share their books with classmates and family members.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the family in that book different from your family?
Can you show me what you could do to make a baby laugh?
Can you count the number of people in your family?
Draw a picture of a really big family. Who will you include?
Can you color and decorate your picture of the big family you drew?
Can you find the letter that makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word watch?
Can you build something fun that your family could ride around in?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. Text copyright © 2018 by Nancy Bo Flood and Rose Ann Tahe. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Jonathan Nelson. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: papers (jannoon028), school supplies (Aleksey Sagitov).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: My Family and Me

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about families, act out some things that families do together, and introduce vocabulary words (grandparents, grandchild).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts My Family and Me and First Laugh—Welcome, Baby!
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Look at and talk about picture cards of animals.
Sort the picture cards that show animals in the same family and pictures that show animals that are not in the same family.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animal families do you know?
Pretend you are your favorite animal. Show how you walk.
How many different animal families do you know?
Draw a picture of your favorite animal with its family.
What crayons would you use to color your picture of the animal family?
What letter is at the beginning of the word animal? Can you write that letter?
Can you use blocks to make a family of your favorite animals? Which one is the biggest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. Text copyright © 2018 by Nancy Bo Flood and Rose Ann Tahe. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Jonathan Nelson. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time for a family fingerplay and to introduce vocabulary (cheers, welcome).
Begin Story Time by rereading the book and asking, How do family members show that they care about each other?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What is the most important thing that family members can do for each other?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Display children’s writing.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you imagine what it would be like to be the brother or sister of a character in your book?
Pretend it’s your turn to make dinner. What will you make?
Who is the tallest person in your family?
Tell me a story about something funny that happened in your family. Can you draw a picture to go with your story?
Draw a picture of yourself doing your favorite activity with your family. How will you color it?
What is the first letter of the word family? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to build a house for a pet?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Increase listening vocabulary of object names and common phrases in English.
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders from the teacher.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify similarities and differences between themselves, classmates, and other children inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Shows understanding by responding appropriately.
